intro: Abutilon avicennae var. violaceum, commonly known as the violet abutilon, is a flowering plant native to Southeast Asia. It is a shrub that typically grows to a height of 1 to 3 meters, featuring soft, hairy stems and heart-shaped leaves. The plant produces showy, pendulous flowers that range in color from pale purple to deep violet, blooming throughout the warm seasons. Its botanical features include small, woolly leaves and a fibrous root system, which help it adapt to various soil conditions. This species is often cultivated for its ornamental value in gardens and as a decorative plant.
distribution_native_art_desc: Abutilon avicennae var. violaceum is primarily native to the coastal regions of southern California and northern Baja California, Mexico. The species is well adapted to the harsh conditions of the Pacific coast. It plays an important ecological role in stabilizing dune systems and providing habitat for coastal wildlife.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Abutilon avicennae var. violaceum was mainly introduced to ornamental horticulture due to its attractive, velvety leaves and showy, violet-colored flowers. This plant thrives in warm, humid climates and is often used in landscape design for its ornamental value.
